messageBody:
I have another question,
I read on the FAQ's site for Junit, saying that if you get a linkage
error, change the excluded.properties file, to include other
packages, and place that in ur classpath before the junit.jar.

What I have done is that I modified the excluded.properties and
added/replaced it in the junit.jar and mounted it.
Is that the same thing, or will it not work?

I tried using the swingui, but it gives me all kinds of exceptions. I
know my tests run thru' the textui, but it gives a classCastException
and a null ptr exception.
would anyone know why?

Also I am using net Beans, so when u say that put it in your
classpath before the junit.jar does that mean mount it before you
mount the junit.jar.

Does the classpath get created in the order you mount the jars?

Thanks a lot for all the help!




--- In junit@y..., Toby H Ferguson <toby.h.ferguson@s...> wrote:
> I think some of the reason people don't use the SwingUI in their
main
> method is because of the desire to use dynamic loading - with a GUI
> there's the notion that the GUI testrunner will be running and will
load
> new classes as/when they become available, so the GUI testrunner
should
> run *its* main(), rather than the class that contains the tests.
>
> Toby
> P.S.
> My biggest gripe is why aren't the test runners properly
documented?
> Nothing in the API docs, nothing in the "how to" docs of any
> consequence. It surprises me that the main entry point of use is
not
> well documented!
>
> Mike Clark wrote:
>
> >parul_49 wrote:
> >
> >>>Most folks generally don't use the SwingUI in the main method,
so
> >>>
> >>it's a
> >>
> >>>little different.
> >>>
> >>>This will work:
> >>>
> >>> junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(Your.class);
> >>>
> >>>Mike
> >>>
> >>
> >>
> >>Thanks for the prompt reply.
> >>Why do u say that most people do not use the swingui in the main
> >>method, how else do they use it? Is it a bad practise to use it?
> >>
> >
> >
> >Most main() methods I've seen use the text UI, though it's not
> >especially a better practice.
> >
> >To fire up the Swing UI, I use:
> >
> > java junit.swingui.TestRunner com.xyz.MyTest
> >
> >Then again, maybe I've seen this more often only because that's
the way
> >I teach JUnit.
> >
> >Mike
